descriptions: The student fails to identify any relevant themes in the documents.
The student identifies a theme, but it is vague or inaccurate.
The student identifies a theme, but the explanation lacks depth or connection to the text.
The student identifies a central theme in the document and provides a basic explanation.
The student clearly identifies a central theme in the document and explains it with supporting evidence.
The student expertly identifies and analyzes multiple complex themes in the document, providing insightful commentary and strong textual support.
The student demonstrates no understanding of the document's purpose.
The student provides an inaccurate or irrelevant purpose for the document.
The student states a purpose, but it is superficial or incomplete.
The student identifies the main purpose of the document.
The student explains the purpose of the document with some supporting details.
The student thoroughly explains the document's purpose, including its historical context and intended audience.
The student does not identify any rhetorical features.
The student attempts to identify a rhetorical feature, but it is incorrect or misapplied.

The student identifies a rhetorical feature and offers a simple explanation of its effect.
The student analyzes how rhetorical features contribute to the document's persuasiveness and meaning.
The student provides a sophisticated analysis of multiple rhetorical features and their cumulative impact on the document's message and audience.
The student provides no textual evidence to support claims.
The student attempts to use evidence, but it is irrelevant or inaccurately cited.
The student provides limited or weak evidence to support claims.
The student includes relevant evidence from the text to support analysis.
The student effectively uses direct quotes and paraphrasing to support claims.
The student skillfully integrates textual evidence to build a compelling and insightful argument.
